website_summaries.verdict: This proves to be an excellent reference book with incredibly detailed illustrations that are easy to compare to real life plants.
pros: Book possesses detailed drawings of plants and has detailed and precise information to back it up about each variation and species
Features convenient and consistent set up with images on one side and information on the other for easy browsing
cons: Doesn’t fully explain how to prepare each edible plant

customer_reviews.title: Great Book For Survivalists and Everyone Alike
customer_reviews.text: While serving with the US Army and during survival training, I found this book to be better than any other. Peterson's Field Guides are okay, but this one by noted outdoorsman Bradford Angier was written with the layperson in mind. I have read numerous "survival" books of his; all are well-written and the drawings by Arthur Anderson make the plants pretty much unmistakable. There is a disclaimer at the beginning, but I highly recommend staying away from plants with white berries, plants with purple stripes and mushrooms. I wouldn't recommend this book for kids, due to the fact that kids would not be experienced enough to positively identify the plants. I also recommend this little article here: [...]
customer_reviews.author: Pho

customer_reviews.title: It's a classic for a reason
customer_reviews.text: I had this book years ago. It eventually got lost. Recently I got interested in this subject again and bought several books on it. Photographs have their merits. But sometimes clearly drawn pictures (and in color) have an advantage over photos. This book is one of these "sometimes". After struggling with the newer books I'd bought (with photos) I remembered this one and bought it again. Money well spent.
customer_reviews.author: Amazonian

customer_reviews.title: Good Companion to Ewell Gibbon's Stalking the Wild Herbs
customer_reviews.text: I bought the book while I was in North Carolina and found useful information on plants that I knew about in my SE locale. Many of the plants featured in this book were specific to the northern states and Canada. I purchased this copy for a friend who lives in Canada. The drawings, color pictures and descriptions of each plant are detailed and precise, with helpful information about the nutritional values of the plants and how to use the parts (roots, stems, leaves & flowers). This was the second edition, I never read the first edition.
customer_reviews.author: Deevoted

customer_reviews.title: This item was damaged. A greasy film was on the cover.
customer_reviews.text: We were intending on giving this book as a gift for our son, but several of the pages were affected by the greasy film on the cover. Overall, the content of the book would've been beneficial to them. Good information.
customer_reviews.author: Gordon I.

customer_reviews.title: Great quick reference guide for edible plants
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this book after checking it and several others out from my local library. It has the best layout of all of them I was able to find. It's easy to flip through because all of the illustrations are on the right page and information about that particular plant is on the left. The drawings show good detail of the leaves, which are in most cases the easiest way to initially identify the plant. Bradford Angier is highly respected in the field, so I trust the information in the book completely. I was able to use the book to positively identify several Serviceberry trees at our local zoo. A nice little snack while watching the bears!
customer_reviews.author: Andrew

customer_reviews.title: Thorough Book!
customer_reviews.text: I am very pleased with this book. It is very thorough, and very easy to get the information needed. Includes alternate names, how each was used in history (natives, pilgrims, etc.), as well as how to prepare and use. Some even warn against including too much of an item in your diet! Can't say enough about this book. Terrific!
customer_reviews.author: Tom

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: very educational and well written with pictures so this id definite read and handy handbook with camping and hiking.
customer_reviews.author: maureen

customer_reviews.title: field Guide to Edible Wild Plants by Bradford Angier
customer_reviews.text: I am always fascinated with edible wild plants, and this book gave me new insights how much we have forgotten about nature's pantry.
customer_reviews.author: Edith Gabriele

customer_reviews.title: Great book.
customer_reviews.text: This book is fantastic. It is informative and illustrates the plants with color drawings which are easier to compare to a plant than photos. It is everything I was looking for in a concise easy to read form.
customer_reviews.author: Leigh

customer_reviews.title: Well done - good graphics
customer_reviews.text: Easy to follow and very useful in identifying edible plants. not a cover to cover read , but an excellent reference.
customer_reviews.author: CBCLI

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: I am enjoying reading through this book learning about the plants and their uses.
customer_reviews.author: CS

customer_reviews.title: great guide
customer_reviews.text: One of the best of many field guides I have read on the subject. The color pictures help a great deal!
customer_reviews.author: Daniel A. Hunt

customer_reviews.title: How to Survive off your suburban lot on just greens!
customer_reviews.text: Yes, the book was in very excellent shape! Thank you so much for asking. Also, it was really well bubble wrapped in mailing envelope! Now I'll be cooking & fetching greens from the yard after I really have identified my greens! I don't want any house members missing from our kitchen home! 👍😱😂
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: A new copy of an old friend.
customer_reviews.text: Brad Angier writes well because he has been there. We are replacing books we loaned and never got back. word
customer_reviews.author: James L. Stanfield

customer_reviews.title: Book is very informative. Bought as a gift, ...
customer_reviews.text: Book is very informative. Bought as a gift, used. It was well worn, but the very low price reflected that it probably would be.
customer_reviews.author: Peggy Freer

customer_reviews.title: The Original Guide to Edible plants.
customer_reviews.text: Having read Angier's guide to wilderness survival, I had to get and read this as the perfect companion volume. i will be doing more foraging on my day hikes this coming season.
customer_reviews.author: Robert W. Hayworth

customer_reviews.title: Good book
customer_reviews.text: I owned this before and I remember it seeming more durable but it is well written.
customer_reviews.author: Guido D Killerpimp

customer_reviews.title: Great book!
customer_reviews.text: An excellent book. The knowledge inside could one day save your life, if you are ever caught out in the wild without having brought food.
customer_reviews.author: Amazonbookreviewer

customer_reviews.title: For Those Well-Informed Concerning Plants
customer_reviews.text: First and foremost, I want to mention that I am reviewing an earlier edition of this book. That said, the Field Guide to Edible Wild Plants is likely to get people interested in the subject, but it does not include information on poisonous plants which one may mistake for one of the plants featured herein. I found the illustrations helpful, and you can check them out in the video component of this review. This is a good book to have in your collection, but it is in need of supplementary material.
customer_reviews.author: Sandy M; Focus Reviews

customer_reviews.title: Better than many others
customer_reviews.text: I find this one useful. Drawings are not "natural" but compensate by revealing all major parts clearly: root, leaf, flower, stems. Anyway, I find one needs at least two books for reliable identity and often for any ID at all. Variations among species make identity of individual plants a lot harder than it might seem, excepting for a few easy plants like cat tails, purslane, etc. I agree with a prior reviewer that absence of poisonous plants is unfortunate. Also, absence of scientific names is not good, since common names aren't reliable.
customer_reviews.author: William H. Mills

customer_reviews.title: A good book
customer_reviews.text: This book first caught my attention in the 70s but over the years I had lost my original copy so I repurchased one. It is still a good book even though the pictures are all rendered as art, which makes me a little nervous on critical IDs. I enjoy the details on preparing the plants, some of which were apparently as the native Americans had done. It is a very good companion book to some of the more recent works out there such as the North American Guide to Edible Wild Plants.
customer_reviews.author: Branchgraft

customer_reviews.title: A little knowledge can be dangerous...
customer_reviews.text: This book is very interesting with nice pictures but should not be used as a primary source in the field. In my opinion, it gives a false sense of security by failing to mention poisonous plants that appear similar to those highlighted. Also, it does not pay particular attention to precise plant identification and therefore should not be used for this purpose. Overall, I have enjoyed this book immensely, but would recommend it with caution.
customer_reviews.author: cassandra mccann

customer_reviews.title: Good, Not Great
customer_reviews.text: Other reviewers caution that this text "should not be your only source"... I agree, but I'd guess that's true of any such reference.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Nice book
customer_reviews.text: Good info and pictures. Easy to use if you know the name. Hard to use in identifying something you found. In order by name, not classes or description. Nevertheless, very helpful.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Saved my Life!
customer_reviews.text: When I was stranded with my dog in the Alaska Wilderness for a week and a half, this book saved my life. Without it, how could I have eaten well until the aircraft came - yes, you heard - eaten well! I thank Bradford Angier greatly for this wonderful text!
customer_reviews.author: George Patterson
